 Note: This game was played on a source port called ECWolf[maniacsvault.net] and I wholeheartedly recommend downloading it to better your experience with the game, adding a few modern features, more resolutions, and turning off the Y-axis so moving the mouse forward doesn't make you move forward as well. I'm going to go out on a limb here and assume most people have heard of Wolfenstein 3D already, but just in case someone hasn't here is a brief history.Though not being the absolute first of its kind, Wolfenstein 3D is a game highly regarded as the progenitor of the first-person shooter genre, created by id Software in 1992, no mater what anyone may say about how good the game is or not these days, it at least has to be respected for the creation of one of the most prolific video game genres to date.You play as William Joseph "B.J." Blazkowicz, a Polish American spy sent on a mission to find out the nazi's plans and stop them, which usually means climbing nine floors and murdering someone at the top or bottom, along the way killing S.S. troops and undead mutants.As you can tell, the story is not really all that important, as famed programmer for id John Carmack once said, and I quote, "Story in a game is like a story in a porn movie. It's expected to be there, but it's not that important." So given this mentality you can pretty much write off the story as just a means to let you shoot stuff, and this was back before most games even bothered to put effort in their plotlines to start with.So that means onto the gameplay, ever played a first-person shooter before? Well then you will fit right at home, the game is simple as far as controls and objectives, you walk around and only are able to look left and right, fighting in stages of block shaped rooms and mazes, looking for keys and doors to get you to the final switch, pulling it and moving onto the next level, there are six episodes and each one has nine levels and one hidden map that is gotten to by finding a hidden elevator in one of the stage, totaling sixty levels in all there is actually a lot of game here.You have three gun types and a knife, though the guns all use the same ammo counter and about the same damage except each one shoots faster then the one before it, levels are sometimes straightforward, and sometimes mazes you must run through, most of the level design is fun and varied up to a point, given they don't have very much to work with other then walls, floors, and sometimes hanging moss.The big question is if it is worth playing, and actually even today, over twenty years after its creation, it is still fun to play, sure it is simple and chances are not anything you haven't seen before from more modern shooters, but it has that old retro charm to it that is hard to explain, it is bright and colorful, has treasure and arcade-like qualities such as lives and a score, and despite how old and dated it seems, I still believe it is worth taking a look at.

 Wolfenstein 3D  The ever so reliable grandad. 1992 ID software released the "Progenitor of First Person Shooters", it is still remembered as one of the greatest classical games of all time. I resently played this using one of its numerous ports, namely ECWolf. It added support for several control schemes much like in a modern shooter, giving me a good reason to jump back in and play it.And bhoyo.. Was it hard. I almost immediately cranked the difficulty to "Death Incarnate" and I have currently blasted through 5 of the 6 total episodes and during that time of pixelated and very profound carnage, I realised something.I was enjoying the game. It was a rather strange feeling, mostly due to not having it happen in a long while. The last game that I remember doing it was Mafia and yes, I realise that it is an entirely different game and it is very narrative driven, but I enjoyed it. Something that cannot be said from some of the games I have resently reviewed. (Fkng Bureau..)Anyway, back to the matter at hand.Although Wolfenstein 3D has aged, it still looks great. There is something about this early-age of computing graphics, that is just amazing. The way they had to work with hardware limitations, limited colours and not to mention floppy drives. Ughh.. I tell you, I resently got one of those cheap USB ones and I suddenly remembered how moody those fkrs are.Where was I? Oh yes.. Even with the age of the game, its pixely graphics and all. It still manages to stay relevant, even after 23-Years. Let's think on that number there for a minute.. 23, a lifetime ago for some people. Including me and for everyone who grew up during the 90's.I keep digressing, I apoligize. But this is partly why people appreciate these games, they are part of their past, their childhood and that is just way too important to ignore.Let's talk about the actual game a little bit, now that I've got the nostalgia chip off my shoulder.The game is an FPS, I can't really explain more than that. It is the most basic of things, get gun, find secret, get bigger gun, kill everything.The game is silly, very much so and it does not give a f**k. The story is the most basic of basics, yet again.The biggest issue that I have with the game, is the level layouts, they are mazes. I remember a wonderfull story of being stuck in one level for a day, just because I could not find the door and to make it better, there is no map system. Hee,hee everyone dies.. 8D There is very little that can be said about the game besides these two things, yet again, it is the first. I know that tere are other FPS games before Wolf3D, but this is the one everyone remembers so.. Meh.I don't think I need to pad this out any longer, I think you got what I'm saying here, right?But to recap.Wolfenstein 3D is a worthwile classic. Even for something of its age, it manages to stay entertaining. The modding and source-port community keeps the game alive, there are numerous mods on sites like ModDB. That can be used to enhance the experience or change it completely. I would highly recommend the ECWolf mod, it is easy to install and only reguires a copy of the game files found in the program folder. Similiar to Brutal Doom in that respect.The game can take a good number of hours to finish, even with the mods making it more playable. But the enjoyment is there and for those brave enough to go-a-romping through Castle Wolfenstein,stay calm,keep a gun handy,and always eat the dog-food when at low health.

												The year was 1995 and I was in 8th grade. I had a friend who spent many of his class periods in separate classes for “developmentally challenged students” (It wasn’t me, I promise). Basically the special teachers would give the special students the answers to tests and do their homework for them so they wouldn’t fail and bring the class GPA down. Anyway, somehow I was able to sneak away from normal kid study hall to go hang out with my buddy every day, and because his school assignments were handed to him on a silver platter, we had all sorts of time to play “educational games” on the school’s nifty Macintosh computer. Back in those days Mac wasn’t exactly known for having enjoyable games, and the school had enough sense to purchase only games that no one would want to play. Titles such as “Wacky Jacks”, “Sim Tower”, and “Dr. Quandry” were the 3 gems we had to choose from. Why all of this non-Wolfenstein related talk? Well I’m getting to that, you see, while the educational powers that be may have done their best to sanitize our academic computer usage of any fun, they overlooked one small detail. One of the games came with a demo to Wolfenstein3D. We loaded that thing up, and study hall forevermore turned into a Nazi bloodbath. The Demo only allowed us to play up to the elevator on the 1st floor, but we killed every last Nazi and found every secret on that level, and once we flipped that lever we would do it all over again. But don’t think for one second that I didn’t learn anything. It became apparent to me after several level one playthroughs that the Nazis lost WWII due to poor resource management. The amount of Hitler tapestries and Nazi flags that adorn the compound hallways must have cost a fortune, imagine if that money had been put into the war effort? The construction of secret passage ways couldn’t be cheap either, and the amount of gold, firearms, and ammunition just sitting around on the ground collecting dust might have been devastating had the Nazis implemented their use against the Allies. Turns out the Nazis fit in perfectly in re-tard study hall after-all. Mein Leben! AIEEeee!!

												The original FPS classic. Make no mistake, Wolfenstein 3D is very dated and has aged poorly in comparison to its sibling DOOM. Lacking even the touches of that game, it really is kind of like Pac-Man with guns.It was also an important historical landmark that put FPS games on the map and set the stage for a lot of what was to come in the genre, as well as ensuring the success of id Software after establishing themselves with the kid-friendly Commander Keen games. These days it's a little hard to believe the game was genuinely shocking in 1992, a time when the ESRB didn't even exist!If you can deal with the sometimes labyrinthine levels, stark texturing, somewhat out-of-place lives/scoring system (the ability to save anywhere makes it moot) and play in chunks to offset the monotony, you'll find a minimalist shooter that rewards tactical thinking as much as it does all-out action. It's a game that ostensibly pushes macho badassery and then puts you in situations that pushes your "badassery" to the breaking point[ellaguro.blogspot.com].If you're interested, I would recommend using the ECWolf[maniacsvault.net] sourceport instead of the DOSBox emulation you get here. ECWolf gives you modern controls and an automap if you're hopelessly stuck. Steam's DOSBox emulation for games is generally poor quality anyway; what you're really paying for are the actual game files, so you might as well use ECWolf if you ask me. Consult this guide to integrate ECWolf into Steamworks so it'll show you as playing the game.If you somehow want even more classic Wolfenstein, the Spear of Destiny prequel features a condensed official campaign - which is good - and two third-party campaigns that aren't really good.

Quick Breakdown: A revolutionary game that helped create the FPS genre proper (there were some iterations of it prior to this). It’s still decent fun, and mandatory playing for anyone interested in the history of video games. It hasn’t aged very well, but still serves as a worthy distraction for a few hours.Length: 3 Hours (Main game), 6-7 (Main + extras)Genre: FPSScore: 6/10Review Date: 2016-07-08Note: The control scheme for this game is pretty dated, I modded it to use more modern controls. I’ll include a link to the source port I used, as well as instructions on what I did at the end of the review.*******************************************************************************************************Full Review: Sometimes you get so used to things just existing that going back to their roots feels like stepping into another world. FPS games technically existed in various highly primitive forms prior to 1992’s Wolfenstein 3D (W3D), but the giant leap forward in gaming that this was may as well have been the start of the genre. At the least, it was the start of the genre proper.Playing the game for the first time nearly 25 years later it’s a bit difficult to truly appreciate what W3D did games. Even compared to Doom released only a year later, W3D feels primitive. And indeed it is, though that’s not entirely a bad thing since it’s still a fun romp. You play as B.J. Blazkowicz, who must escape from a Nazi prison known as Castle Wolfenstein. After doing so, you continue your fight against the Nazis. Set in first person, the game plays only on a level playing field. There’s no crosshair for your weapon, there’s not even variation in the height of the level. You can walk, run, open doors, and shoot. That’s about it, you can’t even look up or down (not that it’s needed here).Gun types are pretty basic as well, with each new gun essentially just shooting faster. You start with a basic pistol, and can pick up a machine gun, and then later a Gatling chain gun. Each gun uses the same ammo, this is before different guns had different ammos. You also have a knife for melee combat, though I never used it during the game.The controls for the game are pretty dated, you walk forward and back, and can turn. Mouse support and strafing need to be modded in to the game. This will also grant you unlimited save slots. Modding it will also allow you to use the Steam overlay, which enables you to take screenshots. (I’ll talk about what I did to mod the game at the end, it’s nothing fancy).Enemies in the game consist of various Nazi troops, and there’s not a whole lot of variety there. Bosses don’t have too much variety either, but you do get to fight Mecha-Hitler, and killing him is a special kind of satisfying.The game features lives, which is a bit odd since you can save the game at any point and reload from there, which is what I did any time I bite the dust. You earn points from collecting treasure scattered about each level, after accumulating enough points you earn extra lives. It’s a small way in which the game shows it’s age.This version of the game consists of 6 chapters, each containing 10 levels (1 level in each is a secret level, none of which I bothered with). The original game only consisted of the first 3 chapters, and will take you around 3 hours to run through. Later releases of the game included an additional 3 chapters (included here). It’ll take about 6-7 hours to complete all 6 chapters.Level design consists of navigating corridors and champers filled with enemies, dead ends, and keys that must be used to unlock doors. The end of each level is marked by an elevator, that when activated completes the level and takes you to the next one. The quality of the level design is a bit inconsistent, some being quite a bit of fun, others being a labyrinthine maze that descends into an exercise in tedium (most of chapter 4). The more combat based portions of the game are among the stronger ones (I think it was chapter 5 that did this well).Levels can get pretty repetitive, and the game would’ve benefitted from some trimming, since better level design wasn’t too likely given that this is a genre in its infancy. As such, I can’t be too critical of it for this, but it’s still a negative.Despite its flaws and heavily dated nature, Wolfenstein 3D is still decent fun. Worthwhile if you’re interested in old school FPS games. It has a sequel called Spear of Destiny if you’re craving more levels, though don’t expect anything fantastic there. Both, along with a third game, Return To Castle Wolfenstein, is available for a mere $10. It’s probably the best way to stretch your dollar. (RTCW is a sequel from 2001, though I’ve yet to play through that one).*******************************************************************************************************Modding Instructions: So for modding, I didn’t do anything fancy or complicated. Here’s a step by step guide:1). Download the ECWolf source port, it’s what I used, and it’s all I needed for this game. It’s based off the ZDoom mod for the Doom games, and works with Wolfenstein 3D, Spear of Destiny, and Super 3D Noah’s Ark (wtf). You can download ECWolf here[maniacsvault.net].2). You need to navigate to a certain folder in your Wolfenstein directory. Since you downloaded it off Steam, by default that’ll be:C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\SteamApps\common\Wolfenstein 3D\baseCopy paste that into Windows Explorer/File Explorer and it should take you there. If not, copy paste the following:%PROGRAMFILES(X86)%\Steam\SteamApps\common\Wolfenstein 3D\baseIf neither of those work, you’ll have to find where you saved it since you’re not using the default location.3). That ECWolf  you downloaded in step 1? Copy/paste the zip folder it gave you into the location from step 1. Then unzip/extract all the contents of that folder into the folder from step 1. (the Wolfenstein 3D\base folder).4). In the same folder, look for something named “dosbox.exe” and rename it to “Steamdosbox.exe”.5). Still in the same folder, look for “ecwolf.exe” and rename it to “dosbox.exe”.Congrats! You’ve now modded your game to feature more modern controls, better key bindings, unlimited saves, and you can use the Steam overlay while in game now. The game is still launched through Steam normally, and it’ll still track your playtime.

												The father of all First Person Shooters. Although not id Software's first FPS, it certainly paved the way for a long-running succession of amazing games over the years. id's passion for details makes this game a valuable piece in every gamer's collection.Just imagine that in 1992 all offices in the world still worked on text-only interfaces, However, id Software came out with a game that further extended previous FPS's capabilities, such as 256 colors (instead of 16), textures, incredible sounds, voices, an excellent music that immerses you in the gameplay and sets the perfect mood, and detailed animated sprites for enemies, as well as an amazing level design throughout the whole game that makes you feel as if you were actually within nazi premises, trying to escape. Basic and easy controls, a choice of only 4 weapons (sharing the same ammo) and a nice amount of secret walls and treasure on each level make this game very rewarding and loveable. id's typical sense of humour can be witnessed throughout the complete gameplay in inter-episode texts, the enemies' speech as they see you and as they die, as well as Wolfenstein's famous PacMan secret level, make this game unique and amazing.Although it is possible to download the game for free, you will be glad to have paid some money for it.Where would FPSs be nowadays if id Software had pursued a different path and never developed Wolfenstein 3D? Would have another company dared make an incursion into FPSs? Would the 2398 Call of Duties of today exist? Or Half-Life?Every FPS in the shelf today owes its existance to this game. And you will not regret having played it.Update: I have happily nominated this game for "The Test of Time" Award for the December Steam Awards :) It is still as good (or maybe even better) as the day it came out.

												Wolfenstein 3D is one of the earliest 3D FPS games ever made. You play as BJ Blazkowicz who is trapped in a Nazi prison and must escape through maze like environments. Through some unexplained reason he starts off with a pistol, which is fine considering the story is barely existent. This Steam version features the extra 3 prequel mission packs that double the amount of episodes from the base game. The prequel episodes are Episode 4-6 but I suggest starting off at Episode 1 since the prequel missions are significantly harder. There are four difficultly settings overall. The first two feature much less enemies so you will not be worrying that much about health or ammo and as a result make it feel more like a puzzle game. The other 2 feature tougher enemies and much more enemies occasionally placed in rather  inconvenient areas. Both offer completely viable playstyles.The gameplay feels more tactical than just running and gunning. A single well placed bullet can take up to 80% of your health and you will not be able to dodge since the game takes a realistic approach as to how fast bullets go through the air. So even the lowest of grunts can kill you if he has a faster trigger finger than you. Luckily they suffer the storm trooper effect of being unlikely to hit anything more than a couple of feet away and even if they manage to the bullet damage is decreased the further away you are. Which leads you to playing very carefully, scouting the area instead of simply rushing through hallways like a supersoilder. There is a 99 ammo limit  which seems like a lot but all the weapons share the same ammunition which leads to more depth as you decide which of the 3 guns are best suited for each situation.The 3 weapons are as follows, a starting pistol which is very effective close range but puts you in risk of a fatal shot, a submachine gun which is pretty solid in medium range but uses up more ammo and a chaingun that annihilates enemies but burns through precious ammunition quickly. There is also a weak knife that you won't be using except in the most dire of situations.  You start off with 100% health and can be regenerated by multiple items including health packs, turkey legs, and dog food. It is a rather strange feeling when you are on the verge of death and are overjoyed to see dog food. Though the real joy comes when you push against a wall and it slides open to reveal much needed supplies and nazi treasure. While we are on the topic of ill gotten goods I should mention there is a scoring and live system. Killing enemies and finding treasure generate points and when you get enough you will receive an extra life that puts you at the beginning of the level with just a pistol when you die. Which I find to be rather odd considering there are manual saves but can be useful if you save at a very inopportune time. Onto graphics. They are very,very outdated, obviously considering the age of the game. But it does negatively effect the experience since all of the walls have the same basic textures which make rooms look basically the same which can be confusing. Added to that problem is the fact that the level design makes no sense. The rooms have no logical rhythm to them and are just randomly stringed together, along with a lack of a map it is needless to say not a game for those that constantly forget where they parked their car. The enemy models look pretty good ranging from German Shepards to Nazi Zombies. There are no ceiling or floor textures either which I didn't find to be much of a problem since most of the game is gray. There are occasional plants and objects thrown about to liven the place up but they may have gone a little overboard with the amount of swastikas and Hitler pictures around. All in all I'd say the 3D effect is awesome but not much else. The sound in this game is good for the most part. Guns sound powerful and add intensity to the gun fights. As for the enemies I have no idea how good the voice acting is since I do not speak German but they do sound rather comical. Though it is extremely helpful since each enemy have their own audio line when they are alerted to your presence which lets you easily identify the type of enemy and their numbers. The metal bunker doors also have a nice sounding effect when opened and closed letting you know that the enemy is on the look for you. Unfortunately the music is pretty bad and gets annoying after a short amount of time. Strangely enough they saved the only good tracks for Episode 3 and they were never seen again. Overall this game is very basic with nothing more to do than search the environment and shoot foes which I can see getting unbearably repetitive for some. You will also need a good sense of direction to get much enjoyment from this game. If you can get past that you will find a very fun game which has exhilarating boss fights,  plenty of secrets and tons of missions to play through. It also has cool secret levels including one where you fight the ghosts from Pacman. So buckle up, find a chaingun and show them Nazis that a guy named BJ is no laughing matter!

												Wolfenstein 3D is the third entry in a series that goes back to the 80's with Castle Wolfenstein and its sequel Beyond Castle Wolfenstein. This installment from the longest running FPS series as of most recent Wolfenstein: The Old Blood from last year takes a new spin on the original titles by the late Silas Warner. The premise is the mostly the same, you're an Allied spy on top secret missions to thwart plans of the Third Reich in an alternative 1940s, often involving the infamous Castle Wolfenstein, a notorious Nazi prison. Wolf3D retells the tale and gives you a name and a face in the likeness of William 'B.J' Blazkowicz, the series' protagonist with many varied scenarios: escaping Castle Wolfenstein, the danger of chemical warfare, twisted Nazi experimentation on POWs to create an expendable army, and even the occult in later installments. Episode 3 of Wolf3D also famously has you assassinating Hitler himself, no doubt a spiritual link to Beyond Castle Wolfenstein which has the same plot. Only this isn't your daddy's Wolfenstein: the Fuhrer packs a few tricks up his sleeve in the since traditional Wolfenstein fashion: a touch of sci-fi in a mostly fantasy WWII setting. History buffs need not apply, for its dumb fun at its finest.Unlike Silas' games, stealth mechanics like moving bodies and disgusing yourself with a Nazi uniform were removed in favor of more action, the transition from a top-down perspective with some of the earliest attempts at visuals to a VGA graphical 3D space in the first person truly set the mark as the definitive first entry for the FPS genre. Especially since you're using a visible gun. Wolf3D's world consists of 3D tiles that make up level design with 2D objects scattered about to flesh things out. The latter's important because architecture is restricted to 90 degree angles making unique geometry limited, with only so much variety. Everything's on one plane leaving you only concerned with what's on the horizon. Interactivity comes in the form of doors and secret pushwalls grant access to hidden medical supplies, munitions and treasure. Oh, and shooting the hell out of any Nazi goon that gets in the way. The most complicated thing is literally acquiring a key or two to unlock sealed off areas, and locating an elevator to leave the floor. Not groundbreaking by today's standards but it paved the way for FPS to come as they rapidly evolved in only a few short years (think: Half-Life came out six years later!).Most common complaint about Wolf3D is the mapping itself, and lack of an automap. The restrictions in architecture and limited number of textures can lead to same-y looking places making it difficult to find your way around. But if you have a good sense of spatial awareness and can recognize landmarks and object placements (and the trail of dead bodies you'll inevitably leave behind when disappearing corpses wasn't cool yet) you won't have too hard of a time. Whether it's id's own levels or fan-made I never have much trouble getting about (the source port ECWolf adds support for an automap however). The 60 maps as well can be an overbearing count at times with 10 per episode: 8 regular, a boss level and a secret level. I find its best to go through one episode at a time as opposed to trying to marathon it as it allows you to appreciate each episode for what its worth.Visually the game is colorful and is notably more cartoony than Doom, but still fairly realistic in portrayal especially in regards to themes: dark prison sections, comfy living quarters, well lit dining rooms, old and precarious looking passageways covered in moss, and luxurious castle areas with rich and clean decor. The variety isn't huge but what's there gets the job done and the attention to detail with the resolution of the textures and sprites they were working with still look convincing to this day, more or less on par with Doom.Gameplay is standard FPS fare and the closest thing to Doom, but with an almost tactical level of survival. You only carry 99 rounds of ammunition and its universal for the three guns you use: a decent pistol that's very powerful at point blank, a reliable (sub)machine gun that's fair on ammo consumption, and the almighty chaingun, while obviously extremely effective is expensive to maintain. Fresh ammo pickups net 8 bullets and used ones dropped by enemies will only contain half that. Overzealous use of the chaingun can quickly deplete your supply, forcing you to fall back on your knife, which is only good against a single enemy. Your health never goes above the base value of 100 and there's no armor. Damage suffered from enemy attacks, which are predominantly hitscan, can seriously injure at close range as the average damage of a bullet in Wolf3D is much higher than it is in Doom. It's not uncommon to be dropped in two shots or being torn to shreds by a single volley of automatic fire. Rushing into unknown areas guns blazing rarely pays off unless your reaction time is high and you have the health and ammo to make it with no or very few mistakes. Divide and conquer and the use of cover is the way to go, unless you clearly have the advantage to be bold and reckless.Enemy cast is small but serve their purpose well. Dogs are the only melee enemy, super weak but often the first on scene due to their speed and can be a nuisance. Guards are dolts with poor reaction time and armed with a pistol but can be dangerous in numbers. SS tote machine guns, their vests keep them going longer, and a small group is very deadly without cover (or a chaingun with plenty of ammo). Officers are fleet of foot, almost as strong as SS, and while they only have a pistol their reaction time is high and they can be lethal if underestimated. Mutants are the rarest, featured in the second episode originally. Almost silent, they're more durable than humans and are even faster than the Officer in attack. And then there's bosses. One is featured at the end of each episode and corresponds to the episode theme. For example Hans Grosse guards the exit/entrance to Castle Wolfenstein and does so with a pair of chainguns. Most bosses aren't too hard to bring down, guaranteed you have enough ammo, but staying out in the open is near suicidal if you don't have enough health.Music is composed by id's then musician Bobby Prince, and while the tunes are strictly Adlib format they all manage to sound unique and moody. It may not be most people's cup of tea but I can't possibly imagine this game with the music off. The music for me is on par with Doom's soundtrack, with many memorable and excellently composed tracks.Likewise, for every good or decent game there's usually something wrong with it. Mainly technical oddities. The enemy can shoot through the door animation but so can you. Enemies also shoot through each other while magically being unharmed which is unrealistic and annoying. No dedicated side step keys and the one sound channel often has sounds cancelling out each other, unless you use a source port.I won't deny that Doom is the penultimate 2.5D FPS as far as overall design is concerned but Wolf3D is still a surprisingly fun and well designed shooter. All thanks to the talented minds of John Carmack for the engine, John Romero for the game design, Adrian Carmack for the artwork, Tom Hall for the vision, and Robert Prince for his audio. There's a wealth of user made content available to this day, ports, and total conversions taking entirely new spins on the game. If you enjoy classic shooters, or just want to see where it all began, it still comes as highly recommended even with its sometimes antiquated design. Who knows, you may find a new obsession, as all the user content available is sure to keep you busy well beyond id's own game.4.0/5

 A Brief History Wolfenstein 3D is a first-person shooter video game developed by id Software and published by Apogee Software. Released on may 5, 1992, for the PC operating system DOS, many believe that this game started the FPS genre for games as we know and love today. Full Review Originally, Wolfenstein was released in parts. However, with the steam release for the game you will have full access to all levels and episodes for you to play through at your own pace. In the full game, there are about 6 episodes, and in each episode there are 9 levels. $5.49 is a good price for a retro game only 9MB in size and has about 54 levels in total.The protagonist's name is William "B.J." Blazkowicz. Blazkowicz is an American spy of Polish desent. The first three episodes of the game are based around B.J. and his efforts to stop the Nazi regime. In the first episode, B.J. over powers his prison guard and escapes the Nazi prison. In the 2nd episode, B.J. finds out that the Nazi army in creating undead soldiers and B.J. tries to stop the evil doctor behind their creation. At the end of the third episode, B.J. faces off against Adolf Hitler in his underground bunker, Hitler is waiting in a robotic suit equipped with four heavy chain guns, these three episodes put together make for an amazing gamplay experience, and challenge which should take about 1.5 hours to complete. (If you don't get lost).If you love the classic game, or just enjoy run-and-gun FPS shooters, then Wolfenstein 3D would be a good game for you, and I would wholeheartedly recommend this game.

												BEST ABOUT IT:  Exterminating Nazis in THREE DEE!WORST ABOUT IT:  The nauseating early 3-D graphics.  Getting flanked by a Nazi and not being able to turn fast enough or one that shoots you from behind a door before the door even opens enough to see them.  Or those planters that they deviously colored just like the Nazis.GAMEPLAY:  The great grand-daddy of FPS.  You navigate a series of mazes to find an elevator and any keys needed to open the doors that block it and are scored at the end of each based on your time, kills, and secrets found.  You're armed with a knife and the 3 guns you can pick up. (pistol, submachine gun, and Gatling-gun).  You can only carry 99 bullets so ammo is always a concern, especially since all your guns share the same rounds and the automatics burn them fast, but that's part of the game's core design.  Many secret passages contain guns and ammo but there's no hint to what walls open, so you just have to rub against them all.CONTROLS:  You can turn left and right and also strafe by holding shift but you cannot look or aim vertically.  It doesn’t seem too picky about your horizontal accuracy either, you just aim in a Nazi’s general direction and drop them (good thing too since there’s no iron sight or crosshairs).STORY:  Kill Nazis go!  You’re a captured spy and the game contains 6 episodes of 10 floors each.  Episode 1 has you tasked with escaping while the others have other objectives such as killing various madmen bosses, including Hitler.GRAPHICS:  They’re bad.  There’s not even a texture for the entire floor or ceiling.  It’s the flattest looking 3-D game you’ll ever see.  But 3 dimensions had to start somewhere and you’re looking at it here.  There’s no resolution or graphics options at all.PERFORMANCE:  This didn’t even tax computers 20 years ago.  It launches in DOSbox and ran perfectly for me.SOUND:  Better than the graphics and there are some memorable Nazi death cries.  The music is creepy yet fun at the same type, a military style and it works well.REPLAYABILITY:  Other than the curiosity or nostalgia factor there is a scoring system and secrets to find but it’s unlikely many people would be compelled to keep playing.  But any FPS fan or retro gamer should at least try this.SIMILAR TO:  Doom, Star Wars Dark Forces, Shadow WarriorRECOMMENDED PURCHASE PRICE:  <$5 (often included in Doom promotions)TITLE:  Wolfenstein 3DDEVELOPER:  id SoftwareRELEASED:  1992 (Steam page is incorrect)80/100

												Wolfenstein 3DGet psyched!Wolfenstein 3D, released in 1992, is ID software’s first major first person shooter. It is a reboot of the 1980’s “Castle Wolfenstein” series made by Muse Software and is arguably the very game that set the fps genre in motion to where it is today. You play as William ‘B.j.’ Blazkowicz, an American WWII spy, who was captured by the Nazis after successfully assassinating superior Nazi officers in charge of a chemical warfare project. Imprisoned in the lowest levels of the German base ‘Castle Wolfenstein’ you manage to kill the soldier guarding your cell, taking his knife and hand gun, and fight your way through legions of Nazi enemies to escape the castle. To quote the admirable John Carmack “Story in a game is like a story in a porn movie. It's expected to be there, but it's not that important.” This perfectly depicts Wolfenstein 3D. The closest you get to a story in this game is a short 1-2 page sample of text at the end of each episode, which summarises the episode you just completed and previews the next one. It is fair to say that the story isn’t this games strongest suit, but what it lacks in story, it makes up for in other aspects.The gameplay in Wolfenstein 3D is undoubtedly its strongest suit. Although today, in comparison to modern games, it may seem primitive and very dated, at the time of its release, fps shooters were still the topic of much amazement. Although it wasn’t ID’s first fps with other titles such as Catacomb 3D already on the market, The Nazi genre had not been done to the extent it has today, and so the WWII setting coupled with the, then considered, extreme violence resulted in an overwhelmingly positive response. There aren’t many weapons in this games, 4 in total, the only memorable one being the chain gun which is where the real satisfaction of shooting in this game lies. It fires bullets at a rapid rate churning threw countless rounds of ammunition per minute, with no reload mechanic making clearing rooms a very satisfying and bloody task once acquired. Although the range of different enemy types in Wolfenstein 3D isnt as large as other games released at the time, they undeniably fit the games setting and genre perfectly and don’t feel out of place. They range in difficulty from the German shepherds and ordinary Nazi troopers being the easiest, to the SS guards, Nazi officers and Mutant soldiers being more challenging encounters. However what Wolfenstein 3D is really remembered for is it fantastic Boss fights. The idea is that you traverse 9 floors in each episode, including one secret floor, and then on the last level fight a Boss. These are the most memorable and challenging moments in Wolfenstein, notably when you get to fight Adolf Hitler himself in a Mech suit wielding 4 chain guns. Unfortunately the majority of the gameplay in this game involves key hunting in order to progress to higher floors which can be a tedious task at times especially on later floors where the maps are extremely big and maze like. Also, due to the limits of the engine at the time, a lot of the environments look the same making it really easy to lose track of where you are, resulting in the painful task of walking around, hoping to stumble across a key or find a familiar looking area. However, the slaughter of Nazi enemies as well as pushing on secret panels throughout each level to find secret areas with tressures inside all make the gameplay enjoyable while you are performing the aforementioned key hunting and other irritating tasks. The soundtracks in Wolfenstein, composed by Bobby Prince, are quite remarkable. Even for a game made so early in video game history, ID was still able incorporate these magnificent soundtracks into the gameplay as well as some games that are made today. The Nazi anthem is played on start-up of the game to get the player in the mood for killing Nazis. Tracks like “Suspense”, “Enemy around the corner” and “Into the dungeons” let off a really creepy vibe which create a very eerie atmosphere when you are traveling down a long empty corridor and hear a door open or close in the distance. “Kill the S.O.B”, “P.O.W” and “Lurking…” are all really suspenseful soundtracks that actually make you feel like an American spy infiltrating a castle, even if there is little to no stealth in the game. Most memorable however is the “End of level” soundtrack which plays as your percentage of kills, secrets and treasures is calculated, making the player feel like they have accomplished something. At the time of Wolfenstein’s release PC’s couldn’t perform at the same level as Nintendo’s living room consoles could. It was John Carmack, lead ID game programmer, who changed this by designing an engine that brought the visual quality of NES games to the PC. Wolfenstein’s Graphics, although dated nowadays, was considered stunning at the time of its release and coupled with the fact that no other PC games on the market looked this good, made it much more appealing to buyers. Level design on the other hand has never been extremely impressive. Due to limits of the engine, there could only be one level/plane meaning no staircases or jump ability. The Maps have a very Maze like design and although may appear like a WWII castle at a glance, due to the brick and wooden wall textures as well as tables and chairs, the layout is very random and confusing resulting in, as mentioned early, the regular occurrence of losing your way.Overall this is a very solid game. The gameplay is enjoyable, and although a few minor irritations may be encountered along the way this is outweigh be the fun of slaughtering hundreds of Nazi enemies. The soundtracks are very unique, it is obvious a lot of effort was put into them unlike some modern fps’ today, which just include a generic action score that no one will remember. The level design and graphics have aged a lot and you would be better off playing with a map of the level beside you to avoid the annoyance of getting lost in the maze like levels. Anyone interested in video games, first person shooters in particular, might find this game interesting as it is one of the most revolutionary games in fps history, however if you have grown up or become accustomed to modern consoles and PC games I would say that you are in for a bit of a shock. 7/10

What I liked about the game 	The game can be additive; I've spent quite a lot of time on the game.  	Awesome boss fights. Some very creative bosses, especially the boss in episode 3. It's not just Wolfenstein, I have also seen this feature in Rise of the Triad and Catacomb; mainly old games, before 1995. You could just save it and forget about the lives feature, but it doesn't feel right; it feels like you are cheating. I'm glad this feature wasn't in Doom. 	There's a lot of blue in the levels, lots of pictures of Hitler and loads of swastika flags, it makes the game very repetitive.	There are only four weapons in the game. You will hardy use the knife and the three guns use the same ammo; there is no rocket launcher or shotgun. 	Episode six is very hard, especially towards the end; its like hide and seek, the Nazis hide you seek and when you find them, you either get killed or  half of your health is gone.	Sometimes you can get lost in the levels, because each level is like a maze, you got to find a key and then you got to find the exit. ConclusionA good game which can be addictive, but if you haven't played any 90's fps games before and you want to try one out, I would probably not recommend Wofenstein 3d, because of its maze like levels and it's repetitiveness. 												Wolfenstein 3D (or "Wolf3D", as we referred to it by its name in DOS) was the first FPS game I ever played, and I have fond memories of it. Firing it up on our old 386 computer was amazing - suddenly this big, heavy beige box, which normally only displayed a very ancient, chunky version of Windows, was now playing a high-speed game with graphics and sound better than anything being done on the various game consoles we had plugged into the TV in the other room. And even though I was never really much good at Wolfenstein back then, its raw display of the PC's power and more importantly, the promise of what was to come for games, made me instantly fall in love with the idea of making computer graphics / games.This version of Wolf3D is better than the one we had on our old PC back then, in that it is the full version with all the episodes, instead of just the shareware copy with the single first episode.The graphics, while revolutionary at the time, are plain but still get the job done. The same can be said for the digital sound.If you've never played it, I suggest you give this game a try. If you're a fan of the FPS genre, it'll give you a good history lesson, and I suspect you'll find that this game is just as fun and engaging as most of the modern titles that have come to succeed it. You might even find yourself yelping and jumping out of your seat, as I recently did, when you zoom around a corner and an unexpected Nazi calls out and begins firing at you. Get psyched!

Posted: August 20, 2016
												So I picked this up on a whim, because I was bored and then Youtube happened, and... ahh, it's like I've been transported back well over a decade into the past.  Back to a time in gaming that I personally thought was pretty darn great.  Had been a few years since I last really played this, but it's amazing how it all comes back...I doubt I need to explain what Wolfenstein 3D is, really.  Pretty much everyone seems to have at least heard of it, and it's role in shaping the industry.  This game was a really, really major thing back then, and it paved the way for Doom, which was an even bigger thing.  But what does it play like?  Compared to modern FPS games, well... there's not much here.  This is an OLD game.  Really old.  I mean, this is back from an era where many people still had game sounds coming out of their PC speakers (do any PCs even HAVE those anymore?).  Back when things like Sound Blaster or America Online were big things. Back when all mice were "ball mice".  Kinda glad THOSE werent around.  Used to have to clean the stupid things by stabbing the internal bits with my car key.  Computers of that time could only do so much, and with a genre that had only just started.  And that does show here.Firstly:  The controls on this game. AWKWARD.  This is something I never really noticed back then, and that's because nobody had really come up with anything better yet.  I honestly dont even remember if the original version of this game had mouse support.  I really dont.  I remember that *I* used just the keyboard.  That's right. JUST the keyboard.  That's how old this is.  And it shows, because there's some very weird things going on with these controls.  Firstly, while you can remap controls, they still wont work quite like you want.  You have a key that you hold to run of course, but you ALSO have a key that needs to be held in order to strafe at all.  While you are strafing, you cannot TURN, because you're using the turn keys to strafe.  This can make things really, really awkward as you move around.  Fortunately there's a way around this:  Look for something called ECWolf, using Google.  It's not a free copy of the game or anything, you greedy snot.  It's something that uses an already existing copy of the game, and adds some "quality of life" features to make it better.  Most important, it lets you fix the controls to be non-awkward.  It also allows you to use a minimap.  That's right, this game didnt have one.  And I know, there's those out there that'd say it "ruins the challenge" to use one.  I say:  No.  Wandering around in areas you've already beaten, over and over and over again, while wallowing in extreme tedium is not "challenge".   Seriously.  Get the minimap.  It'll make your whole experience better, and it WONT ruin the challenge. And the game definitely has alot of challenge to offer you.   There are not all that many enemy types in the game (particularly in the first episode, as that episode also made up the demo version of the game, so only 3 enemy types appear in there), this is true.  But they all tend to hit like freight trains.  Even the absolute most basic soldier can chop off over 50% of your HP if he gets a hit on you up close. And that's with a pistol!  The closer the enemy is, the higher the damage they'll do to you.  And of course, the more accurate they'll be.  And these enemies arent flinging fireballs and actual "projectiles" at you like in Doom.  These enemies are all using proper guns, which means hitscan attacks.  So once they fire, if their aim is true, you WILL get hit, as you'd expect.  So unlike Doom, just running through like a maniac is likely to get you flattened.  The game does a very good job of creating a challenge though without making it feel TOO hard.  And you have four difficulty settings to choose from.One defining feature of this game though is the levels.  These places are true labyrinths in every sense of the word.  Doom's levels were never this confusing.  Loops and dead-ends EVERYWHERE.  And secrets?  Oh yes.  There are secrets.  Despite that ALL secret doors work the same way... they look like a normal wall, but when you hit "use" on them they move backwards about 3 tiles or so... they can be amazingly hard to find.  There tends to be alot of them, and the game absolutely will do things like have one secret room that you find, which then has another secret room in it, which then has a third, which leads to a small maze with doors and rooms and things, one of which has another secret room, which has another secret room, and then your head bursts all over the ceiling.  It does stuff like this alot.While that can be pretty interesting, one thing of note is the game's items.  This isnt Doom where there's all these different powerups and armor and lots of weapons.   There are FOUR weapons... two of which you start with...  and no powerups, no armor.  There are healing items, 1-ups (rare), and treasure.  Treasure increases your score... yes, this game has a scoring system... and counts towards the tally at the end of the stage.  MANY secrets will lead just to treasure.  This game was designed back in a time when scoring systems in games were still a major thing, and when players would go out of their way to get the 10000 points that an extra area might offer.  Because they want the damn points, that's why.   That sort of thing is starting to become more popular again recently, but some players wont really have played any games like that.  And if you dont like things like that, you're likely to find alot of secrets and bonus areas to be, well, not at all satisfying.  But if you're like me, always trying to get scores as high as can be, you'll find alot to search for here.Though I've always wondered just WHERE good ol BJ stashes the hundreds of crowns and treasure chests that he picks up along the way.And all of those things pretty much sum up the actual gameplay mechanics nicely.  Everything meshes well together, but be warned that the game can be repetitive.  LOTS of games are like that of course, but for some this one may be a bit too much in that way.  If that's an issue for you, this is not the game for you.  Also, if you need a big story, and talky bits to make a game interesting for you.... this REALLY isnt the game for you.  The story can be summed up like "You're in this castle, built by maniacs.  Run through mazes and shoot evil Nazi jerks.  Find Hitler, who has a mech suit for some reason, and kill him.  Also kill some other bosses, because bosses. Thus the world is saved. The end!"  And that's all there is to the story.  You never even get to find out where he got that mech suit.  What a cliffhanger.With 60 levels, this is a LONG game.  There are 6 "episodes", with each episode having 9 normal levels, a boss fight, and one secret level (one of which is very unique... you'll know it if you find it).  If you can handle the simplicity and repetition, if you like finding treasure and doing battle against endless waves of evil enemies, finding secrets, exploring... Wolfenstein 3D is a true classic, and should be played through at least once.Just... get that ECWolf program.  It'll automatically notice your Steam installation of the game, and work with it.  You can thank me later.  Or thank me right now, that works too.

												Many years of my youth were spent in these prison walls. This is the real deal, original and amazing. John Carmack is one of my biggest inspirations, and this, in my opinion, is one of his masterpieces. id Software pushed the limits of what PCs could do at the time and achieved the impossible.The settings they chose for DOSBox don't appeal to me however. I am not keen on using filtered graphics. I like crisp pixels. If you would like to see what I mean there, is an easy way to set the graphics very crisp and original feeling, and while we are at it, we can also smooth out animation a lot:1. Right-Click the game in Steam, and choose "Properties".2. Click on the "Local Files" tab.3. Click "Browse Local Files".4. Double click the "base" directory.5. Open "wolf3d.conf" with notepad.6. Look for the "[sdl]" section.7. Change "output=ddraw" to "output=overlay".8. Scroll down to "[cpu]" section.9. Change "cycles=auto" to "cycles=12000".Save and exit notepad.Run the game and enjoy.This smooths out animation greatly, and provides original crisp feeling graphics. Some people prefer the filtered look, if that's you, just leave it as ddraw and only change the "cycles" option.

												Wolfenstein 3D is the granddaddy of the first person shooters. It was developed by ID software and released in 1992. The game is still amazing and very enjoyable, just keep in mind that the game is almost 25 years old (It was released in the 5th of May). The objective of each level is to get to the exit. Sometimes keys are required to progres. In the 9th level of every episode you are required to kill the boss of the episode to continue. The controls are really antiquated, but using the ECWolf source port allows for a mouse and keyboard control scheme. The levels are made out of corridors and all the angles are 90 degrees (due to the engine's limitations). This can create a lot of confusion as the levels feel like a maze (and in episode 6's case, they are literal mazes). The ECWold source port fixes that issue by adding a automap. Wolfenstein 3D is my favourite pre-Quake game. I higly recommend it.

												The great-grandad of the FPS genre. Yeah, it's alright. I didn't like it too much.I know, I'm a horrid person, aren't I? So far, I've only played a couple of id games, and unfortunately this is the first one I didn't really enjoy. DOOM was like a blast of cocaine, and Return to Castle Wolfenstein was like a slightly less better version than Half-Life that I still appreciated. But this? Well... it's just kind of nothing.In Wolfenstein 3D, you follow a similar pattern of old-school gaming platforms that loosely tie a story together as you go and kill more and more enemies (which in this game's case is Nazis). So, most of the issues I have instantly fall towards gameplay. I will say this though, this game has NOT aged well, especially for its controls. I spent a while reconfiguring them for mouse input, but at that point, I could move around by moving the mouse. And the A and D made you look- not strafe- right and left, which was really irritating at certain points. The levels are pretty simple- find the key, kill the Nazis- but their structure definitely isn't. These maze-like dungeous kept me stuck for nearly 20 minutes, just trying to find my way out of one corridor, because all the hallways in this game look the same. Yes, there are deviations of color, but in those specific areas, everything looks the same! It's incredibly easy to start losing your head as you run in constant circles around the same places again and again and again...DOOM aged much easier, since it allowed actually understandable controls and gameplay that anyone could adapt to, with some relatively posh level design. Does that make Wolfenstein 3D a good foundation? Certainly. But does that make it a good game? Frankly no.

												Wolfenstein 3D is single-player First Person Shooter that was released on PC MS-DOS in 1992. It's somewhat official sequel to Wolfenstein game for older computer, a top-down stealth game, yet W3D is neither of those. It wasn't the first FPS ever, no. Few were made before this one. It wasn't the most advanced engine-wise either, it was beaten easily by Ultima Underworld. What matter though, is that it was the first FPS that made the genre popular, as it was all about fast-paced action, running quickly and shooting everyting, exploring mazes, and not requiring a top-computer to be able to run.It would then later recieve more love, get expansion pack and be ported onto consoles and other computers, with some version being inferior and Mac family ports were almost superior to DOS. Superior ports got higher resolution graphics and two additional weapons, with levels remixed. DOS only got 8-sided sprites of enemies, while other ports have 1-sided only, which doesn't matter so much in this game. Oh, and differences in soundtracks and levels too.Now, with it being quite an old game, how Steam version was handled?The game itself is almost same as original DOS version and comes with all 6 episodes. The slight difference is a change of "Apogee" to "Activision", game being brought to Steam at around 2007 year. And they removed help/instructions completely for whatever reason. Probably because ordering info was beyond outdated. Thus no intro story for you.id software screwed up on DosBox part. It lags heavily. But you can fix it, you just have to go to game's folder and edit DosBox config file for Wolf3D, to make it run with OpenGL renderer.Shame that gameplay didn't age well, but it is most eye-pleasing WW2 shooter around from colorful design side, with memorable music being upbeat or funky suspense.The original release of the game had 3 episodes only, each having 8 normal floors, 1 boss floor and 1 secret floor:Escape From Castle Wolfenstein - Classic episode, which came fully with Shareware. Which was like, 1/3 or 1/6 of a game. One heck of demo.Operation: Eisenfaust - In this episode you explore some nasty dungeons only to find a secret entrance to nazy base. This is the only episode which has Mutant enemies, who are just plain nasties, providing a huge difficulty spike, for they are completely silent and can have zero reaction time. Good heavens they weren't used in other levels.Die, Furher, Die - Back to good joy again, this one introduces white officer nazis, who's only advantage is their speed. Still more fun than mutants. And in these set of levels you get to kill Hitler. Even "few". So it's awesome. And secret level is Pac-Man parody.Now, after original release, publishers figured out that id can quickly make additional 3 episodes themed after chemical war, Noctural Missions, and sell them as well. The results are 3 additional episodes that are quite meh and don't provide any new content, aside from bosses and textures:Dark Secret - Not much to be said there, it feel like direct continuation of episode 3, having harder and more complex mazes. Though I doubt that you would more of them.Trail of the Madman - This is where you see id starting to tire out and their creativity starting to sink. It provides simpler mazes than Dark Secret and you can see graphical themes of rooms starting to get even less interesting.Confortation - This is where developers got completely tired and are going to make players tired as well. Design of levels became completely lazy. First floor has you travelling corridors that have sideways every step and you have to check every one so you will not get bulet into back. Later level layout is nothing but nazi cross repeated few times and connected with each other by doors. Final boss is quite generic and is no match for Hitler encounter.After choosing your episode, you have to select your difficulty out of four, all of which have phrases as name, so you wouldn't be able to guess which one is "Normal". I recommend you to pick the second to top, as it will still get difficult at the end and you will not die as much. Due to realistical/hitscan nature of enemy attacks, you often will feel that you died in a cheap way.The game uses keyboard mostly, not exactly comfortable. Buttons it uses are arrows and right shifts, alt, ctrl, so it's kinda cluttered. It also has just one "hold this to strafe" button, so you can't circlestrafe around. Though, in this kind of FPS it would be useless. It also allows usage of mouse. Not for mouselook, nope. More as a replacament for arrows, it's used for movement. Yep, mouse back then was viewed as gimmick and not everybody knew how to make use of them.Your mission is to find exit elevator, while staying alive. To do this, you have to epxlore 1-floor maze of blocks, that are full of enemies, bonuses and doors. As well as 2 keys and locked doors. You know what to do with these. It's also littered with secret pushwalls, where you have to press "open" on a wall that you don't like and it may open, being pushed away for two blocks, revealing a secret passage. But there is no way to tell if this wall is a secret, as some of pushwalls have interesting texture while others aren't marked at all, thus creating uncertainty. Thus the only way to find them all is to hump all walls you see and that's tedius, not fun. MS-DOS version doesn't have any maps, so good luck navigating. The game uses scores and lives system that feel out of place in this not-so-arcadey game. You collect many treasures to increase your score. Nope, High Score Board sure isn't going to make you compete with Steam friends, it's as usual full of blank jokeyish entries. At least it saves your score. It also has lives system, where after death you will begin level again with only pistol and if you run out of lives, you get classic game over. But because you can save and load anytime and anywhere, no one cares.The selection of huge-pixeled (feature of DOS version, by the way) weapons that you get are simple. Way too simple, actually:Knife - Useless.Pistol - Fires bullets.Machine Gun - Fires bullets fast.Chaingun - Fires bullets very fast.You are going to use Machine Gun all the time anyway because Chaingun eats ammo too fast, not being able to shoot just one bullet. So it's pretty poor on thinking.And sure thing fighting enemies if main part of game. Soldiers are preplaced on the maze, standing and sometimes patrolling around, reminding that Wolfenstein 3D was supposed to be stealth game at first, as they take extra damage if they aren't aware of you. Once they notice you or hear you, they will let out some sort of "achtung" voice and start to chase you in a direct way. Nope, their footsteps are completely silent, so on some levels you should listen to doors opening carefully. Rarely it leads to fun mouse and cat scenarios, in which fun suddenly ends by getting shot into back. Most often it means a lot of dead bodies around nearest door. Actually, most often best tactic is to come into room, give a shot and then run back behind doorway's corner, as you just sit and camp, shooting enemies one after another. Not most exciting thing.Main problem comes from the fact that every enemy has only hitscan-based attack. So it's a game more about camping then running out and shooting everybody in a fair fight. And it's randomized in no end, bringing quite a frustation, as each bullet may either poke you slightly or completely kill you. It all depends on distance though, same for your bullets damage. Close range is deadly.Boss fights are disssapointing for video game. All of them are same. Pop out, shoot until they decide to shoot back, hide.  Go to secret stack of supply if it goes bad.So, a game that didn't age well, with cheap core gameplay. Still classic. If you want history, just play Shareware though. And if you do want full game, then only play first 3 episodes in short bursts.

												This is going to be an odd review, for the reason that I will mostly be reviewing this game with the idea that one is playing with a mod to polish this game a little bit, as the steam version feels very blurry and dated, and makes this game feel a lot less timeless than it really is. If you end up buying this game anyway, and try the mod I recommend, it's a good idea to view this as the 2D maze-like puzzle game where you have some sort of fog-of-war, because most can relate to a retro game rather than viewing this with the same standards of call of duty. This game has one serious flaw, and it's that you almost can't play the original version that steam sells.    The mod I recommend here is called ZDOOM, and while it's for Doom, it can be used for this game with a few tweaks. Overall it makes this game feel less like it did in 1992, and gives it the polished feel of a retro game made in the 80's that everyone can play, like Mario. ZDOOM fixes polishing issues in the game, such as resolution fixes, mouse and keyboard if you wish (even though I don't recommend it), texture fixes, and overall gameplay fixes that make this game a lot more timeless while still keeping the original atmosphere. I usually strongly dislike revamping old games (for example, SkyWind makes me cringe), but this fixes key issues that make this game not fun, while stuff like SkyWind just makes the game pretty, killing its original atmosphere and feel of the game.    Now that I've discussed how to be able to play this game with minimal frustrations, I'm going to be straightforward and tell you this is not a good game. I have about 15 hours off steam on this game, and based on my experiences, this game still has some serious problems that can't be fixed with something like ZDOOM. It's really obvious that this game is dated as hell, as it was the grandfather of FPS. You'd really think it's not that bad, but it is. It's a truly unplayable game when you get down to it; it's just not fun. A pros and cons list would be a good way to show this game's worth since ratings for games can be pretty subjective.Pros:- Managable fighting mechanics, ZDOOM gives this game simple controls and easy-to-learn combat. At first I didn't enjoy keyboard controls, but this game's map design really gives an interesting idea with it. The fact that you have to turn left and right does add a bit of challenge since the devs like putting enemies on both sides, and gives strategies that also include a mix of strafing (with alt key), and add a little more extra fun to the table, and trust me, you need that extra fun.- Has creative map layout at points, and the maps that try to be memorable (like secret levels, bosses, and aardwolf maze) are very memorable and I could still point them out. The did some interesting choices with the actual combat itself, and gives a more fun idea of fighting that really gives strategy. Like Doom, this game is known for having some serious consequences for not thinking and responding fast, and really gives some emotion out of the game.- Pretty playable, it's easy to beat a chapter in a day since missions are short and the game can be not enjoyable or bad, but just generic, so you can sometimes play a lot.- Uses an atmosphere and a premise of why you're fighting rather than a linear story, so you can get right into the action rather than having a boring, linear game with no thought put in yourself.- Better mechanics than a lot of modern games (difficulty in this game has more factors for it than Skyrim, and gives some variety there)- There's fun in the idea that there are a lot of modders that add their own flavor to some of the maps, and create their own original weapons and maps, and it's fun to play at least a couple. I'll send one to start with at the bottom of the review.Cons:- 4 types of enemies, most chapters don't show all at once. This really kills a lot of the fun, because it's just you doing the same thing over, and over, and over again, and I can understand that this game was made in 1992, but it just lacks polish for such a big game.- The normal levels really aren't memorable and it just seems like there lacks care in the level design, everything is bland and the same, and it's nothing exciting for so long.- Generic weapons that do the same amounts of damage and use the same ammo, just have different fire rates.- Can feel a bit clunky at times with movement, and looking around.- Overall a generic game, nothing seems exciting, and some points you just get so bored you quit and don't play the game for the rest of the day. All of the missions feel like the same thing over and over again, there's no interesting gun variety, no enemy variety, no variety for any factors in this game, even health and ammo drops are the same over and over again. I'd really say that doesn't make this game bad, but it's just not exciting. It would be different if there were a small amount of weapons but each were very unique, but each small variety of items adds nothing new to the table and feels the same as the last. If you're dealing with small variety and blandness, there's not only no content, but no fun with it, and that's just done poorly.    Overall, I'd really say this game isn't terrible, but it lacks map, weapon, enemy, health, and ammo variety, and ends up feeling like the same game over and over again. I'd personally recommend this over modern day Call of Duty because they're essentially the same game; a generic game with nothing really new or exciting in it. This game is somewhat timeless with ZDOOM, but movement can feel seriously clunky at times and it's just more of "not fun" than a "dated" or "hard" game with today's standards. 												If you're reading this review, chances are you're already famliar with this game.In that case, this port is playable, and you can relive your old memories. Go for it.If you haven't heard of this game, then I recommend going in with an open mind. Wolfenstein 3D was one of the first popular first persion shooters, and helped propel the genre into the spotlight for many teenagers and college aged players. Between this, DOOM and Quake, a new culture spawned around shooters, mods, and map making (especially with the latter two games).However, the graphics have not aged well. If you're the kind of player who has reservations about playing old games because they're "too blocky" and you can't be immersed in that type of environment, then you may want to save your money and play one of the current Battlefield or Call of Duty games.Otherwise, the game mechanics dealing with ammo and health are interesting, the inclusion of secret areas and increasing your score by finding stolen treasure is a nice touch that can give ideas to game developers even today. The maze like structure in this game -- the same kind that was popular in many other games of the time -- may be a bit confusing for those used to always having a map where to go, but it also can help bring a bit more adventure and mystery. After finishing the game, you'll definitely feel a sense of accomplishment, and a new understanding and appreciation for where we've come from, and where we're at currently.

I love everything from the killing of Nazis, the controversy surrounding this game, the secrets, the fun and the plain stupidity of this game.  What I love about Wolfenstein 3D is how stupid it is, but unlike dumb modern shooters, this doesn't treat you like an idiot by shoving tutorials in your face, waiting for you to learn how to play the damn game.  Wolfenstein 3D represents what has been lost from the First Person Shooter genre, which is the soul.I have played countless shooters with a sad lack of soul to it.  Wolfenstein 3D is a great game, and truly one of the finest FPSs ever made on the face of the planet, and that's why I recommend this game.

												Easily one of the hardest, most frustrating and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed FUN games I've played. It is incredibly tough, but not unfairly so- all the resources you need are in the level, with yet more hidden. Level design is a bit archaic- at times it's really just a maze, and the samey wall textures don't help- but learning the maps, finding secrets and paying attention to your surroundings will reward you greatly. Enemy soldiers are unforgiving and have very fast reaction times that you will have to beat to survive, and at times there will be very many of them. It simply has to be played on the highest difficulty.It is an FPS stripped down all the way, demanding from you only raw determination and skill. It's not as brilliantly designed as Doom, nor as clever and intuitive as Quake, but Wolfenstein 3D is still a very worthy member of id Software's trinity of shooters and a classic in its own right.By the way, the game comes packed with Dosbox on Steam. Dosbox sucks. Download ECwolf, copy the contents of the ECwolf folder to the folder named "base" in the Wolf3d directory, delete dosbox.exe, and rename ecwolf.exe to dosbox. Tweak your resolution and controls in the settings, and you're good to go.

												One of the earliest FPS games ever made, Wolfenstein 3D has a lot of historical importance, and with a lot people playing it and having fond memories with it, its still considered a great game. Do I think its good well...Yes and no.First things first this port is crap. Its just a DOSbox shell which would be fine, but the configuration is absolute garbage. You have to do a lot of DOSBOX config changes before the game is even playable.After that you are left with a game that is fun, but only in short bursts. That isn't really a knock against the game as a whole because it was one of the earlist FPS games ever made, but rather a warning to you if you choose to buy it.Wolfenstein 3D has a lot of flaws in 2015 that weren't really apparent back in 1992. The levels are repetetive mazes that are easy to get lost in and theres no map which worsens the issue. The controls by default are clunky and hard to use (though this is fixable but not on this release alone, a source port will fix this) the game is unfairly difficult, the list goes on.But its still a really FUN game.The shooting is very fun and the 3 guns that you get in the game are all fun to use. Especially the chaingun with its loud sounds and sheer power. Killing things is really fun in this game thanks to great sound effects, good hit detection and good animation. The game is fun, but it hasn't exactly aged well, but if you can tolerate its problems Wolfenstein 3D is still a fun game. If anything you should buy for its historical importance. The visuals are basic, no surprise there, but they don't look bad. The sprites are very detailed and the textures look good. The textures do tend to repeat and the levels are complex in design but basic in look. There are no multileveled floors, the levels are flat and static, but again this game was released in 1992 so its okay.The music is really good, I love that twangy Sound Blaster\Adlib sound that many DOS games had at the time and this is no exception. The sound effects are also good.Overall I recommend this game only if you know if you are getting into. You have to know how to tweak the DOSbox config file before starting (unless you get a source port) and this game does have a lot of flaws by todays standards, but its historically important and for that reason alone you should give Wolfenstein 3D a try,

Sure, the voice samples are goofy when guards see you and yell in broken German and let out death cries ranging from cringeworthy to gut bustingly hilarious, but that's part of its charm. 												Wolfenstein 3D still has something to offer modern games who are looking for a bit of nostalgia. Although this wasn't the first FPS, it was the first blockbuster hit that really established the FPS as a genre. However, the game doesn't hold up very well today.Wolfenstein 3D is fun, but also very frustrating. Here are a few problems. 1) The controls are so atrocious that the game is practically unplayable, but a source port program like ECWolf can be used to update the control scheme. 2) The layout of levels is sprawling, and the blocky and repetitive architecture give most levels an annoying maze-like feel. 3) The game is weird with corners, meaning that sometimes enemies can see and shoot you around a corner, but you can't see them. 4) The mutant enemy type will often shoot you instantaneously on sight, without you having time to react. 5) There are only a few types of weapons and enemies, and combat quickly becomes repetitive. 6) The built-in auto-aim can be clunky and unreliable.Ultimately, I recommend Wolfenstein 3D because it is still fun to play despite its many failings, which admittedly will keep some FPS fans from enjoying it. My advice is to play it with the ECWolf source port (or another like it), and to enjoy the game in small doses, playing a level or two per day so that it won't become tedious. If you want some nostalgia and can appreciate an older game in spite of its limitations, then Wolfenstein 3D is a good buy.

												Wolfenstein 3D is clearly a rough predecessor to DOOM; there's a lives system that doesn't make sense considering the save function, there's only one ammo type, the levels are of a uniform height and are easy to get lost in, there are fewer of DOOM's level design tricks (that is to say, putting an enemy in a corner you normally wouldn't look in), both you and the enemies are far easier to kill, and there's just less content overall. In addition, it helped popularize first person shooters for an audience that probably hadn't seen one ever before, but then DOOM came along and...well, you know. For pure quality and importance to game history, DOOM is superior in pretty much every way.However, on its own merits, it's a decent game that drags a little too much in the middle and was enough of a hit at the time to allow id Software to go onto bigger and better things. Also, it makes fun of the Nazis by portraying them as straight-up cartoon villains with mech suits and swastika-shaped bases and Hitler vampires, so that's good. I'd say buy it to experience a piece of gaming history, 'cause that's what I did.EDIT: I did not play the Nocturnal Missions, because 1) they didn't come with the original release, and 2) once you've killed Hitler, you've won the game as far as I'm concerned.

So, as inexpensive as it is to have one of the most vital pieces of gaming history to enjoy for yourself, you would be kind of silly not to get it and try it at least once.
